citeinfo.origin: National Science Museum, Tokyo, Division of Fishes
citeinfo.title: Fish Databases of Japan

abstract.p: Nine institutions in Japan collectively contribute to three databases: the Collection Database including fish specimen data from approximately 250,000 lots; the Map Database produced on the bases of information from the Collection Database; and the Type Specimen Database. The Collection Database comprises specimen data contributed by seven institutions (museums and universities: see below). The Collection Database primarily includes data from specimens collected in Japan and adjacent waters, but also includes specimens collected from other regions of the world. The images stored in the Type Specimen Database are composed of color photographs and radiographs. Although many type specimens are recorded in the Type Specimen Database, more are being added. Please direct any questions, comments, or corrections to Keiichi Matsuura (matsuura@kahaku.go.jp), or other participants in this project.

Search Help: Taxonomic searches are done by family, genus, species, and/or subspecies. If you are not familiar with fish classifications, you may click "Family Browse" to show a table of family names. Each family name is a hyperlink that retrieves images and other data for all corresponding records.

descript.purpose: To collect and archive fish specimen.

idinfo.useconst: The museums and universities listed above retain all rights, including copyright, which may be contained in data, files, and/or images. Commercial use of databases is prohibited.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system. NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.
